description.narrative:
Insatsen bedöms viktig för att främja inklusiv tillväxt i Etiopien, på grund av de flerdimensionella hinder som uppstår i ekonomin till följd av låg och ineffektivt fördelad kapitaltillgång för privat näringsverksamhet i landet. I flertalet studier av tillväxt och fattigdom i Etiopien utmärker sig tillgång till finansiering som ett huvudsakligt hinder för hållbar, dynamisk och inklusiv tillväxt. Detta är fallet i synnerhet för små och medelstora företag (SME), som är mest utmärkande och irrationellt förfördelade vad gäller tillgången till kapital i förhållande till deras potential att växa och skapa arbetstillfällen och förbättrade inkomster för biståndets målgrupper. SME-företagen bedöms vara särskilt viktiga för landsbygdens kvinnor, som idag för sin försörjning ofta är beroende av improduktiv självhushållning eller mikroföretag med begränsad potential för tillväxt, expansion och ökade inkomster.
I den kontexten är en holistisk ansats till finansiering önskvärd, en ansats som i flera avseenden adresseras av IFC (International Finance Corporatiopn) i deras nyskapade finansieringsprogram Ethiopia PSD Initiative Access to Finance (A2F). Trots att IFC:s erfarenheter i Etiopien bara sträcker sig tillbaka till 2008, så har institutionen på dessa år ackumulerat värdefulla insikter och nätverk medan dess globala erfarenheter och resurser för privatsektorutveckling i fattiga länder är mycket omfattande och användbara även i den lokala miljön. Detta skapar förutsättningar för IFC att komma igång relativt snabbt med relevanta operationer inom ett genuint ramverk för styrning och kontroll. En ägarskapsfrämjande efterfrågeledd ansats till bistånd tillämpas samtidigt, där programmets olika delar skapas på direkta önskemål från privat och offentlig sektor.

This programme addresses Access to Finance as a critical bottleneck to pro poor growth in Ethiopia. Via engagements for capital markets development, improved SME banking options, leasing practices, corporate governance practices and credit reporting infrastructure, the programme sets out to create 8 0000 new jobs, lift 30 000 people above the 1.25$/day and improve incomes for the 40% of the population

description.narrative: BACKGROUND TO CURRENT RESULTS STATUS The initial contribution to the A2F Trust Fund was made in late 2014, as a trial intervention to enable IFC capacities in development finance in a more dedicated financial sector programme than the original IFC-led Investment Climate trust Fund (EICP 1) could conceptually host. Access to Finance in itself was such a big development challenge to Ethiopia within the investment climate framework, that it was assessed to need a development intervention in itself. (See also Economisti/BKP report "ACCESS TO FINANCE IN ETHIOPIA: POLICY, REGULATORY AND ADMINISTRATIVE IMPEDIMENTS" from February 2014.) The group of donors who supported EICP at the time had already signed a memorandum of understanding with IFC to establish a governance platform (Multi-Donor Initiative, MDI) which would host an Access to Finance initiative in addition to the EICP. Sweden by its initial contribution enabled the A2F initiative to establish, and was assessed to be able to cover a start-up period of around 18 months. During this period, other donors would be expected to come in and a more mature Trust Fund framework was supposed to be in place and operating from end of 2016. The initiative was slow to develop. World Bank and IFC had both sought Government approval of major credit lines to Ethiopia during 2014. GOE approved the World Bank (government-channeled) credit line, but rejected the IFC credit line, as they didn't want any direct engagement by multilateral institutions towards the private financial institutions. The World Bank credit line enabled a retained high level of government control. This impacted priorities within the World Bank Group with negative effect for IFC. IFC were put on hold while World Bank initiatives were developed. While DfID gave up about MDI A2F delivery along the way, instead reorienting their A2F budgets towards emerging World Bank initiatives such as the SMEFP, three other donors had come on board by 2017 or early 2018 (Netherlands, USAID and Italy). Since then, the proposed intervention areas have slowly evolved, in spite of challenging conditions, and there has been some interesting progress and developments although the original core pillar of SME financing never gained significant momentum in the shadow of SMEFP. USAID decided in 2017 to to cancel their second trance of support to MDI A2F (earlier agreed at 1 MUSD). In spite of related disappointments, Swden decided in late 2018 to fill the gap in operations which had been left by the USAID exit. An updated results vision and action plan for the time up to current Trust Fund deadline (December 2019) was developed. By end of 2018, the A2F Trust Fund has matured to a point where Sweden had expected it to be by mid term (mid 2017). STATUS OF RESULTS Targeted Value of financing facilitated in 2018 was 0.5 MUSD, while the accumulated programme outcome was 2,680 MUSD. This shows a strong trend, while the programme overall lags behind target by more than 50% (2,754 MUSD instead of 7,937 MUSD). It should also be mentioned that most of the financing facilitated to date has been facilitated from multilateral and public sources, not from real private sectors, which has been the core ambition from Sweden and the only value facilitated which really counts towards the FFD agenda and in OECD statistics on mobilized capital. Another interesting trend and result is that the 2018 sales revenue of intermediaries in corporate governance (targeted at 10,000 USD) achieved 16,946 USD. This means that accumulated results from the beginning of the programme (40,390 USD) is catching up to, and by now actually exceeding, the overall programme target (set at 40,000). This is good news, since the Swedish Embassy bilaterally "seed funded" the Ethiopian Corporate Governance Institute (EICG) under the PSD Hub Phase II programme (hosted under Addis Chamber). ECGI is now a core client of MDI A2F. ECGI is so far evolving well beyond the original Swedish Funding, and benefits from technical assistance from IFC for its continued development. It was an explicit goal by the Swedish Embassy to see the ECGI reach financial autonomy, and to collect any necessary donor support from a donor pool rather than from Sweden as a bilateral donor. Value of Leasing Financing to SMEs increased by 31 MUSD over the 6m reporting period, well above period target of 20 MUSD, and total accumulated value during the programme is now 43 MUSD compared to a target of 20. The period target of "number of individuals trained by the project or project trained institutions" was 1181, at par with target of 1216. The accumulated figure for the programme is now 4404, beyond target of 3550. The number of trained individuals who were "satisfied or very satisfied" with the trainings was 2262, higher than the surprisingly conservative target of 800. The number of women trained was 640 compared to 200 for the year, 1090 compared to overall target of 732. This is good progress, but targets seem unreasonably conservative with regards to reaching women. While the number of laws/regulations affected by the programme reports progress well below target for the period as well as overall (4 vs 13 and 4 vs 20), success has been better at firm level where procedures and standards improved in 19 instances over the year (compared to a target of 13). Progress on reaching women borrowers is well behind target.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
